'Parade' ~ parade, assume at least 3 meanings + Time. 1) Freud: A DIFFICULTY IN THE PATH OF PSYCHO-ANALYSIS(1917) "I will say at once that it is not an intellectual difficulty I am thinking of, not anything that makes psycho- analysis hard for the hearer or reader to understand, but an affective one - something that alienates the feelings of those who come into contact with it, so that they become lessinclined to believe in it or take an interest in it. As will be observed, the two kinds of difficulty amount to the same thing in the end. Where sympathy is lacking, understanding will not come very easily." 2) Moses | Trojan Horse  | Joshua 'Karen Horney' Whores Jericho Walls  3) "The New Mission of Judex" serial 4) Chaplin "The Floorwalker" (1916) satire of Futurism and Marcel Duchamp (get one back for the 'team'). I've been making surreal digital collages and now that my work is starting to get a little attention, people are beginning to ask me that age old question about surrealism: What does it mean? or What am I looking at here? Often I don't know what to say, there really isn't any hidden meaning, usually I just put together elements that just seem to look right together, I like leaving room for interpretation , I like hearing what others think it's about, it may be something I never even thought about when making it. I love surrealism and I'm  not sure why , I guess it's like what what said in the video, it's a blend of the familiar and the strange. I find realism kind of boring, as an art professor once told me:"if you want realism , go take a photograph." I like the dreamlike quality to it, I like searching for meaning in surreal work. Any other artists out there who have been asked the question of what it means, and what do you say?

Surrealism is when you stare at a field of golden wheat outside of a car window, and see it turning into the sandy dunes of a land long forgotten, or an endless sea with impossible ships wearing sails of cloud. Surrealism is the desire to explore our worlds and others, Surrealism is the embodiment of imagination. This is why so many people love the works of artists like Rob Gonsalves. The images they create are more than just paint on canvas, but a chance to return to the land of fairy tales we all end up leaving as we grow up.

Romanticism, Pre-Raphaelitism, Aestheticism, Symbolism, Expressionism, Dadaism, and Surrealism have always been my favourite art movements. As a brief introduction to Surrealism, this is great. That said, what is missing from this lovely little video is, quite frankly, the recognition of women artists in the movement. Frida Kahlo (though she rejected the label), Leonora Carrington, Remedios Varo, Leonor Fini, Kay Sage, Dorothea Tanning, Louise Bourgeois, and others should at the very least be mentioned. The art establishment, from museums to art history books, have neglected to recognize the importance and influence of women artists all the way through to this past century. We're only beginning to acknowledge just how substantive their contributions are and I find it more than a little disappointing that this video continues to perpetuate an androcentric narrative. It's true that in the past the established art world has been a "boys' club", but that has changed, and needs to continue to change.

Amazing video, though I don't think you mentioned how problematic BrÃ©ton was + the blatant misogynies he published in his written Manifestoes of Surrealism. The image of the femme-enfant, or the Woman subject stuck in arrested development (thus rendered without any speck of agency), are one of the most harmful depictions of the Woman and her autonomy in Surrealist works. Still to this day we see traces of the woman-child; the 'damsel in distress' trope, the 'baby burlesk' as popularized by our girl Shirley, and moreso in Nadja, Carroll's Alice (published a decade earlier), and to an extent Nabokov's Lolita. Salvador Jurado Nice to see someone whoâ€™s educated on this topic :)! I think Frida cannot be seen as separate from Diego. They met in 1928, when Frida was only 21 years old.  Fridaâ€™s most mature works were created throughout her later life, in parallel with what happened to her in the course of that life (her relationship with Diego, her stay in the US, her miscarriages, her health struggles etc.). She painted without commercial purpose, purely as a way of coping with her life and herself. And what a funny way of you to say she â€œjust so happened to marry Diego Rivieraâ€: they had a very intense and turbulent relationship and their encounter wasnâ€™t incidental. In a way, they were destined to be together (with similar backgrounds as Mexican artists and socialists). Also, an artistâ€™s merit or quality isnâ€™t necessarily proportionate to the artistâ€™s fame as you seem to suggest (e.g. Van Gogh, early Picasso, ...). Anyways: I for sure keep my opinion: Khalo was a â€œtrue artistâ€, for she painted with authenticity as a way of coping with her difficult life. She didnâ€™t bother about what people might think of her work. In her art, RiviÃ¨ra is a motive and object of love, trust, or jealousy, as their relationship was intense and turbulent. Fridaâ€™s artistic life is connected to him almost from the very start (21 years old). And if she hadnâ€™t ever met RiviÃ¨ra, she would still have enough/other sorrows to base her art on.     Tbh I really donâ€™t get your point, sorry :/
NARNIA!!!

â€‹Â @lvo3617Â  I'm sorry to come so late in this conversation but I don't think that being called an "true artist" should be associated with coping with a difficult life or reacting to what people think of their works. This whole video shows the impact the french surrealist males had on art in the XXth century, their impact only is enough to call them true artists.     Caravaggio, Michel-Angelo, Raphael, Boticcelli, Delacroix, even Picasso and Matisse, for examples, all of these true artists did react to the world surrounding them, they did bother about the reception of their works, because one has to be in the world to make an art revolution. They did bother, and yet they did change the standards of their time. To react to the world, to have interactions with other artists and the audience of your work does not take away your authenticity. Without any interactions nobody would even make art at all. Authenticity is for me an empty concept, it doesn't exist as an absence of any influence on one's mind. Absence of influence cannot exist, even if you claim it. Without any influence people wouldn't even talk or think. Dali and the others are not less authentic than Khalo. Of course they lived in an artistic sphere where influence was important, but does that make them less authentic ? If it does then let's get rid of most of artistic movements, without which Khalo wouldn't have painted the way she did...

Â @OlivierDuvergerHoupertÂ  Thatâ€™s very well put, thank you. I am revising my opinion ;) The discussion on what makes a â€œtrue artist" is empty. Once again another brilliantly informative video, my only criticism is that the lack off music. For me, the use of music in your videos is a key element to remembering key facts about the subject in question. For example the use of Beethoven's 8th symphony in "the case for Mark Rothko", every time I listen to it, it floods my mind with information linked to Rothko and abstract expressionist as a whole therefore helping me remember important information. Furthermore listening to the background music of any "case for" video is a huge help when i personally feel creatively 'dry'. Please consider the power that the music has on the viewer when crafting your next video.

Doesn't this omit, amongst other things, the elements of (1) choice of the artist and (2) judgement of the viewer. (1) The artists may have used juxtaposed contrary objects, but they had to choose which ones to exhibit, I can't see that the process was anywhere near as automatic as is claimed - they were editing all the time. ISTM they were was a significant amount of self-control. (2) Why is it that some images resonate, eg the fur cup and saucer, and others, apparently equally absurd, do not? If this was random then all images would resonate equally wouldn't they?
